features.title: Dead Hedge

pages.textPreview: A living boundary made from stacked branches and brash. It’s a quiet larder and shelter belt for insects, birds, and small mammals.

features.description: A living boundary made from stacked branches and brash. It’s a quiet larder and shelter belt for insects, birds, and small mammals.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Fresh growth along the hedge line brings early insects—watch for busy birds collecting nesting material nearby.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Peak invertebrate season: pause to listen for buzzing and scan blossoms and leaf edges for caterpillars and beetles.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Seeds and berries draw birds; look for fungal fruiting bodies on damp wood after rain.
seasonalNotes.Winter: A shelter belt in the wind—spot roosting birds and look for tracks where animals use the hedge as cover.

features.story:
At first glance it looks like a tidy pile of sticks. But the Dead Hedge is really a busy apartment block disguised as a boundary.

Step closer (politely). In the gaps and shadows, small lives rehearse their daily routines: hiding, hunting, nesting, nibbling, and not being eaten.

If you stay still for long enough, you’ll notice the hedge is never actually still. It’s a soft edge where the farm quietly says: “Yes, you can live here too.”

features.title: Fallen Tree

pages.textPreview: A reminder that ‘dead’ wood is full of life. Look for fungi, beetles, and the tiny habitats that form as the trunk slowly returns to soil.

features.description: A reminder that ‘dead’ wood is full of life. Look for fungi, beetles, and the tiny habitats that form as the trunk slowly returns to soil.

seasonalNotes.Spring: New leaves and rising sap bring activity—scan the bark for beetles and listen for birds feeding on hidden larvae.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Warmth speeds decomposition: look for ants, wood-boring beetles, and sunning reptiles nearby.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Prime fungi time—after wet weather, check the log for brackets, mushrooms, and softening bark.
seasonalNotes.Winter: A winter larder: woodpecker holes and peeled bark can reveal where birds have been hunting insects.

features.story:
The Fallen Tree has retired from standing up, and it’s never looked happier.

Where a trunk meets the ground, the whole plot thickens: fungi move in with quiet confidence, beetles arrive like tiny engineers, and birds turn up for the buffet.

Wilding has a sense of humour—what we call “fallen” is often the start of an entirely new career. This is a slow-motion feast, a shelter, and a nursery all at once.

features.title: Giant Chair

pages.textPreview: A playful landmark and a perfect pause-point on the walk. Sit, look out across the site, and notice what’s flowering, buzzing, and moving.

features.description: A playful landmark and a perfect pause-point on the walk. Sit, look out across the site, and notice what’s flowering, buzzing, and moving.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Great for spotting the first waves of blossom and fresh green—listen for dawn birdsong and nesting bustle.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Use it as a butterfly-and-bee lookout—scan sunny edges where flowers meet longer grass.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Watch the colour shift and seed heads form; birds often move along hedges and rides at this time.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Clear views for silhouettes and tracks—look for winter birds moving in small flocks across open ground.

features.story:
Some landmarks are ancient standing stones. Some are giant chairs. Hooke Farm contains multitudes.

The Giant Chair is a polite invitation to do the most wilding-friendly thing possible: stop. Sit. Breathe. Look.

From here you can watch the site behave like itself—flowers leaning, insects commuting, birds complaining, and grasses waving as if they’ve heard excellent gossip.

features.title: Hen Henge

pages.textPreview: A wonderfully odd feature with a name that makes you smile. It’s a small stop that hints at how the farm mixes usefulness, humour, and habitat.

features.description: A wonderfully odd feature with a name that makes you smile. It’s a small stop that hints at how the farm mixes usefulness, humour, and habitat.

seasonalNotes.Spring: A good stop for noticing new growth and early insects—hover a moment and watch the edges come alive.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Expect constant small movement: flies, beetles, and bees working the sunny side of anything sheltering.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Look for fallen feathers, seed heads, and foraging signs—edges become busy as food gets patchier.
seasonalNotes.Winter: A sheltered nook to pause in wind and rain; look for footprints and the quiet patterns of daily routes.

features.story:
Hen Henge sounds like something you’d stumble across in a myth, right after a mysterious fog and just before a life-changing cup of tea.

In reality, it’s a small reminder that wilding isn’t only serious science—it’s also joy, curiosity, and the occasional splendidly silly name.

Stand here for a moment. The best features don’t shout; they wink. And this one definitely winks.

features.title: Ichthyosaurus

pages.textPreview: A Jurassic nod tucked into the landscape. A place to think about deep time, local stone, and the layers beneath our feet.

features.description: A Jurassic nod tucked into the landscape. A place to think about deep time, local stone, and the layers beneath our feet.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Low sun and fresh growth make textures pop—great for noticing stone surfaces, lichen, and tiny plants in cracks.
seasonalNotes.Summer: In heat, stone holds warmth—watch for basking insects and listen for the hum of summer nearby.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: After rain, colours deepen; look for moss brightening and fungal spots appearing around damp edges.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Best season for form and silhouette—clear air and low light make the ‘deep time’ feeling strongest.

features.story:
Imagine Dorset when it was sea, and the sea was busy.

Ichthyosaurus is your doorway into deep time: a playful nudge that says, “Everything you’re standing on has stories older than trees.”

Touch the idea more than the object. Let your mind swim backwards through layers—then come back to the present, where lichen writes its own slow, living script on stone.

features.title: Green roof

pages.textPreview: A roof designed to be alive: planted, insulating, and rich in micro-habitats. Great for invertebrates, and a lovely example of ‘built’ nature.

features.description: A roof designed to be alive: planted, insulating, and rich in micro-habitats. Great for invertebrates, and a lovely example of ‘built’ nature.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Look for fresh sedum/plant growth and early pollinators on warm mornings; tiny flowers can be surprisingly busy.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Peak bloom—expect bees and hoverflies. Heat shimmer and scent can be strong on still days.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Seed heads and dried stems provide structure; watch for spiders and late insects hunting in the shelter.
seasonalNotes.Winter: The roof becomes a hardy, low-maintenance habitat—notice evergreen patches and frost patterns clinging to plants.

features.story:
Most roofs have one job: keep weather out. This one has two: keep weather out and invite wildlife in.

The Green Roof is a tiny meadow that decided to live on top of a building. It drinks sun, holds heat, and offers a miniature neighbourhood of crevices, stems, and shelter.

If you ever need proof that “built” and “wild” can be friends, this is it—quietly blooming above your head like it planned it all along.

features.title: Barn Owl Box

pages.textPreview: A nesting site built to support one of the farm’s most iconic hunters. Keep your eyes open at dusk for silent flight along field edges.

features.description: A nesting site built to support one of the farm’s most iconic hunters. Keep your eyes open at dusk for silent flight along field edges.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Breeding season begins—keep a respectful distance. Dusk is best for a chance of a hunting pass along edges.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Long evenings: watch low, wavering flight over rough grass. Listen for calls near dark on still nights.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Young owls disperse; hunting can be active as nights lengthen—scan fence lines and field margins at dusk.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Hard weather pushes hunting into daylight edges; look for pellets beneath roost spots and near posts.

features.story:
A Barn Owl Box is a promise with a hinge: if the habitat is right, the wild might accept the invitation.

Nothing about a barn owl is loud. You don’t get a grand entrance—just a hush, a pale shape, and suddenly the field is listening.

So this is a place to practice dusk-patience. Watch the edges. Let the evening arrive. And if you’re lucky, you’ll see the silent sentence of flight written across the air.

features.title: Monkey Puzzle

pages.textPreview: A striking, spiky silhouette that’s hard to miss. A small landmark to orient yourself—and a great spot for photos in changing light.

features.description: A striking, spiky silhouette that’s hard to miss. A small landmark to orient yourself—and a great spot for photos in changing light.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Fresh greens around it make the spiky silhouette stand out—great for contrast photos and listening for birds.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Strong midday sun can be dramatic; try early morning or golden hour for softer light and more wildlife movement.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Moody skies and changing colour palettes make this a standout landmark—look for birds feeding nearby.
seasonalNotes.Winter: The classic season for silhouettes—frost and low sun can make the structure feel almost sculptural.

features.story:
The Monkey Puzzle doesn’t just sit in the landscape—it declares itself.

Its branches look like they were designed by a whimsical architect who only had triangles and attitude. Birds treat it as a lookout tower; walkers treat it as a compass.

If you ever lose your bearings, find the spiky silhouette and reset. The tree is basically saying: “You are here. Now go notice everything.”

features.title: Tree Lith

pages.textPreview: A tree-and-stone moment that invites a slower look. Notice textures—bark, lichen, moss—and the small lives that hide in the cracks and shade.

features.description: A tree-and-stone moment that invites a slower look. Notice textures—bark, lichen, moss—and the small lives that hide in the cracks and shade.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Look for new leaves, fresh moss, and early insects on the sunny side; birds often forage along textured bark.
seasonalNotes.Summer: In shade, it stays cool—good for spotting butterflies resting and spiders’ webs catching the light.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: After rain, colours deepen; lichen and moss glow. Great time for fungi on nearby wood and roots.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Best for reading structure: bark patterns, lichen maps, and the way stone holds damp and frost.

features.story:
Tree Lith is a small stage for big details.

Bark becomes a map. Lichen becomes handwriting. Moss becomes velvet. Stone becomes a sun-warmed seat for an insect that will never know it’s sitting on geology.

This is a place to swap speed for attention. The reward is that everything you thought was “background” becomes the main event.

features.title: Toad Pond

pages.textPreview: A watery corner for amphibians and pond life. In spring you might spot spawn, in summer dragonflies, and year-round the signs of hidden visitors.

features.description: A watery corner for amphibians and pond life. In spring you might spot spawn, in summer dragonflies, and year-round the signs of hidden visitors.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Peak amphibian season—look for spawn and listen for evening calls. Tread carefully near pond edges.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Dragonflies and damselflies patrol the margins; watch for tadpoles and water beetles in shallows.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Leaves fall in—look for frogs/toads sheltering nearby and birds coming to drink on quiet days.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Life slows: amphibians overwinter nearby. Scan the surface for ice patterns and the edges for tracks.

features.story:
Toad Pond is the farm’s small mirror—reflecting sky, reeds, and whatever dares to move across the surface.

In spring it becomes a nursery; in summer, an airshow for dragonflies; in autumn, a quiet drinking place; in winter, a lesson in patience.

If you want to meet the shy residents, bring stillness. Water rewards the slow.

features.title: Old Mill Pond

pages.textPreview: A calm patch of water with a sense of history. Watch for ripples, reeds, and the birds that patrol the margins.

features.description: A calm patch of water with a sense of history. Watch for ripples, reeds, and the birds that patrol the margins.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Birdsong and nesting activity ramps up; look for new reed shoots and early insects skimming the surface.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Watch for dragonflies, swallows, and the shimmer of life on hot days; early mornings are often best.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Migrants may pause; falling leaves and softer light make reflections beautiful—look for fish ripples.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Quiet and reflective—scan for winter birds and note how water levels and vegetation change.

features.story:
Old Mill Pond keeps its secrets in ripples.

Stand still and you’ll see the whole place rearrange itself: a shadow passes under the surface, reeds sway like they’re whispering, and birds patrol the edges with professional focus.

It’s a history-heavy kind of calm—water that remembers. Visit often and you’ll notice it never tells the same story twice.

features.title: Orchard

pages.textPreview: A pocket of fruit trees where blossom and fallen fruit feed the food web. Listen for bees in spring and birds in autumn.

features.description: A pocket of fruit trees where blossom and fallen fruit feed the food web. Listen for bees in spring and birds in autumn.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Blossom season—stand still and you’ll hear bees. Watch for pollinators and early butterflies on warm days.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Fruit begins to form; look for birds feeding and insects working leaves and flowers in the understory.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Fallen fruit draws wasps, thrushes, and small mammals—great time for busy, messy abundance.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Bare branches reveal structure; look for lichens, buds, and winter birds using trees as perches.

features.story:
The Orchard is where the farm quietly practices generosity.

In spring it throws confetti (blossom) for the bees. In summer it grows weight and sweetness. In autumn it lets the ground become a feast. In winter it stands back and shows you the architecture of branches.

It’s a place where food is never just for humans—and that’s exactly the point.

features.title: Public Bridleway

pages.textPreview: A shared route through the landscape—part access, part corridor. Edges like this are often wildlife hotspots, so walk slowly and scan ahead.

features.description: A shared route through the landscape—part access, part corridor. Edges like this are often wildlife hotspots, so walk slowly and scan ahead.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Hedgerows and verges green up fast—look for early wildflowers and listen for territorial birds.
seasonalNotes.Summer: A corridor for butterflies and bees—scan sunny banks and flower-rich edges as you walk.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Berries and seed heads draw birds; look for mushrooms on damp verges after rain.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Great for tracking: footprints in soft ground and clear views of birds moving between cover.

features.story:
The Public Bridleway is a shared thread—human footsteps, hoof prints, and wild routes braided together.

Edges are where stories happen: hedges hold nests, verges hold flowers, and cover holds creatures that would rather not be seen.

Walk it like a guest, not an owner. If you keep your pace gentle, the bridleway will show you the busy life running alongside it.

features.title: Wild Veg Garden

pages.textPreview: Where growing food meets letting things get a bit wilder. A mix of beds, edges, and ‘volunteer’ plants that invite pollinators and predators alike.

features.description: Where growing food meets letting things get a bit wilder. A mix of beds, edges, and ‘volunteer’ plants that invite pollinators and predators alike.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Seedlings, blossom, and early weeds all appear—look for hoverflies, ladybirds, and the first bumblebees.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Peak pollinator time—scan flowering herbs and edges. You’ll often see predators too: spiders, wasps, and birds.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Harvest season plus seed heads—leave some stems for overwintering insects and watch for late foragers.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Structure matters: piles, stems, and compost become shelter. Great time to notice ‘habitat gardening’ in action.

features.story:
The Wild Veg Garden is what happens when you stop insisting on perfection and start inviting allies.

Yes, there are vegetables. And yes, there are weeds. But the real magic is the conversation between them: flowers calling in pollinators, predators arriving to keep balance, compost turning yesterday into next month.

It’s a kitchen garden with a slightly untamed grin—growing food while quietly growing habitat too.

features.title: Wildflower Meadow

pages.textPreview: A broad brush of colour and nectar when the season is right. The best place to linger for butterflies, bees, and the constant, quiet movement of grass.

features.description: A broad brush of colour and nectar when the season is right. The best place to linger for butterflies, bees, and the constant, quiet movement of grass.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Early flowers begin to appear; watch for the first butterflies and listen for skylark-like energy overhead.
seasonalNotes.Summer: The headline season—nectar, butterflies, and bees. Visit on warm, still days for maximum activity.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Seed heads and grasses take over—look for finches feeding and late blooms hanging on.
seasonalNotes.Winter: A season of structure: stems, frost, and tracks. Notice how ‘empty’ meadow still shelters life.

features.story:
Wildflower Meadow doesn’t do stillness. It does shimmer.

On a good summer day the air is full of wings: bees commuting, butterflies zig-zagging, and grasses nodding like they’re keeping time.

Come back in autumn and it turns into a library of seed heads. Come back in winter and it becomes sculpture. The meadow is always working—just at different speeds.

features.title: Insect Homes
features.sourcePdf: JH WW24 info Board - Insect Homes.pdf

pages.textPreview:
You may have noticed these piles of stone
around the site - they're insect cairns. We
use them as markers for the butterfly
transept. They're made from waste stone
dug up from our yard.
INSECT APOCALYPSE
 Please read 'Silent Earth' -
it's a revelation about the
plight of insects and why
we need to be concerned
about them.
LEARNING ABOUT INSECTS
Remember that insects are a vital ingredient in the w…

features.text:
You may have noticed these piles of stone
around the site - they're insect cairns. We
use them as markers for the butterfly
transept. They're made from waste stone
dug up from our yard.
INSECT APOCALYPSE
 Please read 'Silent Earth' -
it's a revelation about the
plight of insects and why
we need to be concerned
about them.
LEARNING ABOUT INSECTS
Remember that insects are a vital ingredient in the web
of life. They are food for birds and fish, which are, of
course, in decline too.
The brilliant thing about our wilding project is that
insects love it - and I love them.
In part, my interest was sparked by Dave Goulson, author
of numerous books about insects. He explained that
there has been a devastating decline in insects over the
last 100 years.
INSECT HOMES:
I've become fascinated by insects and have seen lots
of different types at Hooke Farm - many of which I
didn't know existed.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Early warm spells bring the first pollinators—watch sunny stones and nearby flowers for activity.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Peak diversity: hover over flowers and watch the cairns for beetles, ants, and bees coming and going.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Late nectar becomes precious—look for final foraging bursts and spiders hunting around the structure.
seasonalNotes.Winter: A shelter season—many insects overwinter in crevices; avoid disturbing and look instead for tracks and birds hunting.

features.story:
This is where the tiniest residents get the best housing.

Insect Homes are both practical and poetic: a handful of materials arranged so that beetles, bees, and other busy workers can shelter, breed, and quietly keep the whole place running.

If you want to feel hopeful, watch the entrances for a minute. The traffic tells you the ecosystem is clocking in for work.

features.title: Rats

pages.textPreview:
We think this is a rat hole!!
We’re delighted to find that we have rat holes
around our garden - and embrace them.  They play
a crucial role in our eco-system for example by:
“Why do we want certain animals around us and not
other animals? In new build homes, facilities are made in
the cavity to provide bats with a home. At the same time,
rats are controlled with clamps, glue plates and poision.”
…

features.text:
We think this is a rat hole!!
We’re delighted to find that we have rat holes
around our garden - and embrace them.  They play
a crucial role in our eco-system for example by:
“Why do we want certain animals around us and not
other animals? In new build homes, facilities are made in
the cavity to provide bats with a home. At the same time,
rats are controlled with clamps, glue plates and poision.”
 Scavenging:  Rats help clean up by
scavenging and consuming waste carrion
which can reduce the spread of disease.
Seed dispersal:  They can help with plant
propagation by spreading seeds.
Being prey:  They serve as a food source for
many predators such as snakes, owls and
other birds of prey, such as buzzards and red
kites.

seasonalNotes.Spring: As food sources shift, watch for fresh signs near compost and edges—remember they’re part of the wider food web.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Activity is often at dawn/dusk—look for runs through vegetation and listen for rustling in cover.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Foraging ramps up—fallen fruit and seeds attract many animals; predators may follow the same routes.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Tracks in mud or frost can reveal paths; avoid feeding or leaving waste that concentrates animals unnaturally.

features.story:
The Rats board asks you to do something brave: swap disgust for curiosity.

Rats are not a fairy-tale villain here—they’re part of the system. They clean up, move seeds, and, importantly, become food for predators.

Wilding isn’t about choosing “cute” animals. It’s about letting the whole cast do their jobs, even the ones with terrible PR.

features.title: Standing Stones
features.sourcePdf: JH WW24 Info Board - Standing Stones.pdf

pages.textPreview:
The standing stones were installed
in September 2020. We chose them
straight from the quarry at
Marnhull Stone near Sturminster
Newton.
The stone is from the Corallian
group of limestones which are
about 160 million years old and they
were deposited during the Jurassic
period between 145 and 201 million
years ago, when the sea level was
retreating!
The stones arrived on an
articulated lorry
At lea…

features.text:
The standing stones were installed
in September 2020. We chose them
straight from the quarry at
Marnhull Stone near Sturminster
Newton.
The stone is from the Corallian
group of limestones which are
about 160 million years old and they
were deposited during the Jurassic
period between 145 and 201 million
years ago, when the sea level was
retreating!
The stones arrived on an
articulated lorry
At least a third of each
stone is underground
They were installed by our
wonderful digger man,
Kevin Holt
STANDING STONES

seasonalNotes.Spring: Lichen and moss can brighten; morning light shows texture beautifully—good for slow, close looking.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Stone holds heat—watch for basking insects and listen for the hum of summer along nearby edges.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: After rain, colours deepen; low sun makes shadows dramatic and highlights the stones’ shapes.
seasonalNotes.Winter: The best season for silhouette and geology—frost and low light reveal form without distraction.

features.story:
The Standing Stones are time travellers with excellent posture.

They’re modernly placed, but the story in the rock is ancient: Jurassic seas, retreating water, and limestone laid down layer by layer when Dorset had a very different job description.

Walk around them slowly. The stones don’t move, but your perspective does—and that’s the trick.

features.title: Wild Bees & Birds
features.sourcePdf: JH WW24 Info Board - Wild Bees & Birds.pdf

pages.textPreview:
Wild Bees & Birds
These bird boxes were built for swifts but we think
they are too low - and the swifts wouldn’t have liked
the creeper either.  The first occupants were starlings,
but the bees usurped them - European honey bees
(Apis mellifera).
However, one rather brave or foolish starling returned
this year and made his or her nest in one of the holes
between the bees.  It wasn’t a great succes…

features.text:
Wild Bees & Birds
These bird boxes were built for swifts but we think
they are too low - and the swifts wouldn’t have liked
the creeper either.  The first occupants were starlings,
but the bees usurped them - European honey bees
(Apis mellifera).
However, one rather brave or foolish starling returned
this year and made his or her nest in one of the holes
between the bees.  It wasn’t a great success as the
bird died - presumably killed by the bees.
I love it when they form clusters like in the photo.  At
times we could see honey seeping through the wood.  I
think that the swift boxes are a bit small for all the
bees that want to live there, but they don’t seem
deterred!

seasonalNotes.Spring: Nesting season begins and bee activity rises—watch entrances for comings and goings on warm days.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Peak buzzing: look for clustered bees and busy flight paths; early morning and late afternoon are often best.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Colonies prepare for colder weather—activity can spike on sunny days as they stock up.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Mostly quiet outside—look for shelter use and remember many insects and birds are conserving energy.

features.story:
This feature is a tiny soap opera in wooden real estate.

Boxes were built with one tenant in mind, but wilding has a way of saying, “Nice plan—here’s what actually happened.” Bees moved in. Birds negotiated. Outcomes varied.

The lesson is simple: provide habitat and let nature handle the casting. The best stories are never fully scripted.

features.title: Our Sweet Track

pages.textPreview:
Our Sweet Track
A ‘Sweet Track’ is a Neolithic timber walkway
and was originally part of a network of tracks
built to provide a dry path across marshy
ground. The trees were cut using stone and
flint axes making planks from oak, ash and
lime, whereas the poles were made with hazel
& alder.  The track found by Ray Sweet was
preserved in the peat bog and it was thought
to date back to around 3800 BC…

features.text:
Our Sweet Track
A ‘Sweet Track’ is a Neolithic timber walkway
and was originally part of a network of tracks
built to provide a dry path across marshy
ground. The trees were cut using stone and
flint axes making planks from oak, ash and
lime, whereas the poles were made with hazel
& alder.  The track found by Ray Sweet was
preserved in the peat bog and it was thought
to date back to around 3800 BC!
Our Sweet track is made from
sweet chestnut stakes and oak
planks.
The idea for its installation came
from Andrew George, from Wessex
Wilding.  It was constructed by a
small team headed by Joe Wood -
in the early stages helped by
Jasper Rayner and later by Bertie
Clark. They’ve all been involved in
a number of projects at Hooke
Jasper & Joe
Joe & Bertie
Andrew George

seasonalNotes.Spring: A great time for a slower walk—fresh growth and damp ground highlight why raised paths matter.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Use it as a calm route through busy habitat; early morning walks can be full of birdsong and insects.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Falling leaves and softer light make it atmospheric—watch for fungi on nearby wood after rain.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Best for reading the land: tracks, stems, and silhouettes. Take care on slippery boards after frost.

features.story:
The Sweet Track is an idea that keeps getting reinvented: “How do we cross wet ground without fighting it?”

Neolithic people built their answer out of timber. Hooke Farm built theirs out of sweet chestnut and oak. Different centuries, same problem-solving.

Walk it and imagine the original track under your feet—then look up and notice how wilding turns a path into a place.

features.title: The Bat Egg

pages.textPreview:
We were very proud of our beautiful
bat egg. Built from waste stone to
house a few different bat species
with a specal cave inside.
But I think the bats knew more than
we did - they visited but never
settled. And then the egg collapsed,
first on one side and then the other,
in the past year.
We are not planning to rebuild it but
let it become a glorious ruin covered
in wild flowers.
Stone carver, …

features.text:
We were very proud of our beautiful
bat egg. Built from waste stone to
house a few different bat species
with a specal cave inside.
But I think the bats knew more than
we did - they visited but never
settled. And then the egg collapsed,
first on one side and then the other,
in the past year.
We are not planning to rebuild it but
let it become a glorious ruin covered
in wild flowers.
Stone carver, Tom Clark,built the bat
egg, finishing in December 2021.
www.tomclarkstonecarver.co.uk
Be Careful - it’s not
safe. Please don’t
go close to it!!!
The Bat Egg
has collapsed!
Pipistrelle bats weigh between 3.5
and 8.5 grams, but can eat up to
3,000 insects in a single night!
They may be living in the crevices
of the bat egg.

seasonalNotes.Spring: As evenings warm, bats return to feeding routes—dusk is the moment to watch above hedges and open rides.
seasonalNotes.Summer: Peak bat season—try a still, warm night for the best chance of activity. Listen for insects too.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Feeding intensifies before winter—watch for late dusk flights on mild evenings.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Bats are largely inactive/hibernating—this becomes a place to think about shelter and seasonal cycles.

features.story:
The Bat Egg is a story about ambition—and nature’s right to disagree.

It was built with care and imagination, and then the bats did what bats do: they inspected, they visited… and they chose other plans.

Now it’s becoming something else: a ruin, a texture, a wildflower stage set. Wilding loves a second act.

features.title: Hibernaculum

pages.textPreview:
It's an underground home that
amphibians and reptiles use
throughout winter to protect
themselves from the cold.
There are lots of frogs, toads and
newts in or near our ponds. They
love the boggy ground and sunny
spots.  By creating a hibernaculum
we have provided a safe space for
them to hibernate over winter.
HOW WE CREATED THE HIBERNACULUM
We lifted an area of turf about 1
by 2 metres and dug o…

features.text:
It's an underground home that
amphibians and reptiles use
throughout winter to protect
themselves from the cold.
There are lots of frogs, toads and
newts in or near our ponds. They
love the boggy ground and sunny
spots.  By creating a hibernaculum
we have provided a safe space for
them to hibernate over winter.
HOW WE CREATED THE HIBERNACULUM
We lifted an area of turf about 1
by 2 metres and dug out the soil
at a depth of 50cm
We used old tiles to create entrance
tunnels into the centre
We then filled the hole with rocks &
logs to create crawl spaces
We covered this with loose soil and the
original turf was laid on top
We made sure the entrance tunnels were
accessible
As the logs decompose
they release heat
warming  the
hibernaculum and
making it an ideal
hibernation habitat for
amphibians & reptiles
WHAT IS A HIBERNACULUM?
OUR HIBERNACULUM
It was inspired and built by
Oscar McCarthy, in May
2022. He has been working
here helping with land
management since 2021.

seasonalNotes.Spring: Amphibians and reptiles begin to emerge—nearby sunny patches can be productive for sightings.
seasonalNotes.Summer: A quiet refuge from heat—look around the edges for signs of use, but avoid disturbing entrances.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Animals seek shelter as temperatures drop—this is when safe overwintering spaces matter most.
seasonalNotes.Winter: The headline season for a hibernaculum—leave it undisturbed and think ‘shelter, not spectacle’.

features.story:
The Hibernaculum is a five-star winter hotel for creatures who hate central heating.

Built from logs and rocks and good intentions, it offers the kind of shelter that lets amphibians and reptiles make it through cold weather safely.

It’s not a feature you “see” so much as a feature you provide. And that’s the whole wilding point: you build the stage, then you let the actors arrive on their own timetable.

features.title: Mount Scotland

pages.textPreview:
MOUNT SCOTLAND
My husband, Jamie Macdonald, is proud of his
Scottish heritage so we decided to dedicate this
mound to him.  It includes 3 Scot's Pine trees and 2
driftwood stags.  The stags were bought in
Bridport market and made from driftwood which
originated in Indonesia - sadly, as a result of the
horrendous deforestation  However the wood
was drifting for some time before being made into
scul…

features.text:
MOUNT SCOTLAND
My husband, Jamie Macdonald, is proud of his
Scottish heritage so we decided to dedicate this
mound to him.  It includes 3 Scot's Pine trees and 2
driftwood stags.  The stags were bought in
Bridport market and made from driftwood which
originated in Indonesia - sadly, as a result of the
horrendous deforestation  However the wood
was drifting for some time before being made into
sculptures, which makes them very resilient to
the weather.  The antlers were provided by Jamie

seasonalNotes.Spring: Fresh growth makes the mound feel newly shaped—good for wide views and noticing the season turning.
seasonalNotes.Summer: A bright landmark: visit early or late for the best light and to avoid harsh midday sun.
seasonalNotes.Autumn: Great colour season—watch for shifting tones in grass and trees, and listen for migrating birds overhead.
seasonalNotes.Winter: Clear air and low sun create strong silhouettes; a good spot for dramatic skies and long shadows.

features.story:
Mount Scotland is a love letter disguised as a landscape feature.

It’s part family story, part artwork, part viewpoint—Scots pine on a mound, driftwood stags standing watch, and a name that carries a grin.

Come here when the light is changing. The mound turns the farm into a panorama and makes even ordinary weather feel like an event.
